question: 'Eggshell' calcification in the hilar lymph nodes is a feature of which of the following?
Which of the following drugs is a 5-lipoxygenase pathway inhibitor?
What is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia?

A medicolegal doctor is called to perform a post-mortem examination. He gives an incision starting from one inch below the symphysis menti up to symphysis pubis without cutting the umbilicus. What is this incision called?

A 45-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with progressive shortness of breath and dry cough. She has a history of joint pain and red eyes as well. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, widespread pulmonary lines, and honeycombing. Which of the following would the patient be suffering from?

A 12-year-old boy came to the emergency department with complaints of abrupt onset of high fever with shaking chills, productive cough, and mucopurulent sputum. On gram stain, numerous pus cells with gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci were observed. Which of the following is the most likely organism?

A 4-year-old boy has a 1-month history of recurrent cough with wheezing. There is no history of previous similar complaints and no family history of asthma or tuberculosis. Examination shows enlarged cervical nodes and bronchi. Chest X-Ray shows air trapping on the right side during inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of difficulty in breathing, noisy harsh sounds produced during inspiration, and high-grade fever for 2 days. What will be the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old male child is brought to the emergency room because of recurrent wheezing. He is on inhaled steroids. His mother gives a history that he has daytime symptoms> 2/week and nighttime symptoms > 2/months. On spirometry, his FEV is > 80% with a PEF variability of 30%. He gets diagnosed with asthma. What is the classification of severity of asthma in this patient?

A 6-year-old child has a sudden onset of dyspnea with wheezing. On physical examination, he is afebrile but has absent breath sounds on the right. His temperature = 37 °C, pulse = 82/minute, respiratory rate = 28/minute, and blood pressure = 100/60 mm Hg. An arterial blood gas measurement shows pO2 = 95 mm Hg, pCO2 = 25 mm Hg, and pH = 7.55. Following the administration of 100% FiO2 by nasal canula, a repeat measurement shows pO2 = 95 mm Hg, pCO2 = 25 mm Hg, and pH = 7.55. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A middle-aged male presents with a two-week history of severe shortness of breath and fever. On examination, he is cyanosed with bilateral coarse crepitations all over the chest. Chest X-Ray shows bilateral lung infiltrates, with O2 saturation of 88% on room air. What is the next best investigation as part of management?

A 20-year-old thin, tall boy presented to the emergency room with sudden onset of cough, severe shortness of breath, and chest pain. He recently arrived from the USA after a 16-hour flight. Immediate chest X-Ray was advised with the suspicion of pneumothorax. Which chest examination finding best reveals pneumothorax?

answers.option: Hyper-resonant percussion note on the affected side
Increased breath sounds on auscultation on the affected side
Resonant percussion note on the affected side
Increased chest movements on the affected side
Dull percussion note on the affected side

question: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with shortness of breath which is gradual in onset along with dry cough for the last 5 years. On examination, there is the clubbing of fingers and bilateral basal end respiratory crackles are audible. Chest X-Ray shows bilateral lower lobe subpleural reticular shadowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 4-year-old boy is brought to you with complaints of fever and cough, persistent for the past 6 weeks, and has lost his weight in this period. On examination, of the chest, crepitations and a wheeze are audible on the right side of the chest. Labs show hemoglobin (Hb) of 9 gm/dl, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 60 mm/hr, and induration in Mycobacterium tuberculin (MT) test is 11 mm. How will you treat?
What is the amount of air a person can breathe in beginning at the normal expiratory level and distending the lungs to the maximum amount?
The DNA damage due to radicals formed as a result of radiation is an example of which of the following?
A medico-legal doctor is performing the autopsy for the opening of the skull during post-mortem in a newborn baby. How should the incision be done?

answers.option: Over the top of the head from right ear to the left ear

question: The most important difference between a forensic autopsy and a pathological autopsy is that in forensic autopsy:

answers.option: It is a valid documentary evidence in the court of law
Done in cases of unnatural sudden or suspicious deaths
Cause of death is usually not known but has to be determined
External findings are of vital importance
All cavities are opened even if injury is not found

question: What is the main advantage of R. Virchow's technique of autopsy?

answers.option: Body can be made available to relatives in 30 minutes
Each organ can be studied in detail
Preservation of vascular supply in pathological lesions
Spread of infection (HIV, HCV) can be limited

question: Which of the following most commonly results in violent asphyxia deaths?

A medico-legal doctor was called by the state law authorities to perform an autopsy on a suspected poisoning case. A detailed study of the stomach and its contents is usually done by which of the following?

answers.option: Can be opened by any side
Opening by incision on its anterior wall

question: A 9-month-old child is brought to the clinic for the assessment of cough. On examination, his respiratory rate (R/R) is 52 breaths/minute with no chest retractions and no wheeze on auscultation. How will this child be classified according to Integrated Management of Newborn and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI)?
In a putrefied body death resulted from drowning, diatoms are found in which of the following organs/viscera?

answers.option: Hilum of right lung and right ear
Ileum and under surface of liver

question: If pulmonary function test shows FEV1/FVC ratio is more than 0.70 with decreased total lung capacity (TLC), then the interpretation would be:

answers.option: Non-specific reductions in FEV1 and FVC

question: Which of the following is the correct Light's criteria for LDH serum ratio in exudative pleural effusion?
Which of the following is the most common causative organism of pneumonia caused due to faulty air conditioning?
Which of the following drugs is a mast cell stabilizer?
Which of the following arteries is most commonly blocked in autopsy in case of coronary atherosclerosis?
Which of the following is correct regarding the dissection of the heart during autopsy?

answers.option: The ventricle is opened first, followed by the atrium
The direction and order does not matter
Opposite to the direction of blood flow
In the direction of blood flow

question: Which of the following organs is not dissected in detail during autopsy?
Why is dextromethorphan an antitussive drug?

answers.option: It increases the intensity of dry cough
It inhibits the activity of cilia
It increases the threshold for cough
It is an NMDA receptor agonist

question: A physician prescribed an anti-tuberculosis drug to a patient. He started feeling a tingling sensation. What could you give to reverse this effect?
What is the concentration of oxygen in air?
Which of the following findings in a body confirms death by drowning upon postmortem examination?
Compared to an abstract, a synopsis does not have which of the following?
Non intrusive form of autopsy in which computed tomography (CT scan) and magnified resonance imaging (MRI) are used is known as?

A 7-year-old boy decides to put beads in his mouth to blow out on his sister but he accidentally aspirates the beads. One day later, he develops dyspnea, a temperature of 98.4 F, decreased breath sounds and a dull percussion note over the right lobe. Sputum shows normal flora. What is the diagnosis?
Which of following will confirm that a parapneumonic effusion has changed into empyema?

answers.option: Pleural glucose to serum glucose ratio > 1
Pleural LDH to serum LDH ratio < 0.6

question: Which is the most important side effect of salbutamol that is dose-dependent?
A collective dose of radiation to a population can be expressed in which unit?
Which of the following is least likely to cause a radiation hazard?
A person commits suicide by slitting his throat, and dies of an air embolism. How did air enter his circulation?
Which of the following is released by macrophages to activate Th1?
Caplan syndrome consists of which of the following two features?

answers.option: Rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

question: A 65-year-old female patient, who suffered from cerebral infarction 3 weeks ago, recovered and started walking. She suddenly started getting tachypneic and died within 30 minutes with failed attempts of resuscitation. Autopsy finding revealed saddle embolus in the pulmonary artery. Which of the following caused the death of the patient?

A healthy male jogger fell down while running and suddenly developed difficulty in breathing. On clinical examination, his left lung was hyper-resonant and air rushed out when a tube was placed in the right lung. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What type of hypersensitivity is seen in asthma?
Atopic asthma most commonly manifests at what age?
A man, who is a miner by occupation, is exposed to dust particles. Which particle deposits in the lower lobes of the lungs?
A pneumonia patient has a CURB-65 score of 4.0. How will you manage the patient?

answers.option: Intensive care unit (ICU) and high-dependency unit (HDU) for severe pneumonia
Admit in ward and administer antibiotics

question: Which of the following increases in obstructive pulmonary diseases?
What is the treatment for hypersensitivity pneumonitis?

answers.option: Antibiotics and removal of antigen exposure
Glucocorticoids and removal of antigen exposure

question: A 6-year-old child presented to the clinic with lethargy, drooling, and high grade fever. On examination, he has epiglottitis. What is the most common causative agent of his condition?
Rain is usually slightly acidic with a pH of 5.6 due to the presence of carbon dioxide. In acidic rain, a pH of 4.6 is found due to the presence of which of the following two components?
What is the treatment for croup?
Which of the following gases is found in the upper part of the atmosphere and absorbs ultraviolet rays but is dangerous when found near the surface?
Which of the following defines the term 'half-life' of a radioactive isotope?

answers.option: The time taken by half the mass of the isotope to decay
The time taken for the radioactive activity of the isotope to decrease by half
The time taken by the entire isotopic mass to decay
Half of the time taken by the radioactive isotope to decay

question: Gamma Knife is classified under which of the following medical techniques?
Which field in medicine comprises of the practice of using radioactive isotopes which give off small amounts of radiation?
Nuclear medicine comes under which of the following fields?
Which of the following refers to the study of man and machinery in a workplace?
What is the management of epiglottitis in children?

answers.option: Examine the throat with a tongue depressor

question: What is the ideal situation for a dead body to be stored in the mortuary?

answers.option: Body is refrigerated but not frozen

question: A body is received from a crime scene in which the death is suspected to be from strangulation of the neck. What type of incision should be made in this case?
A body was found with a horizontal mark on the neck and ecchymosis around it. It is a case of strangulation which is different from hanging. How is strangulation different from hanging?

answers.option: Ligature mark in strangulation is more horizontal
Hanging causes a deeper ligature mark
Multiple ligature marks are seen in strangulation
No ecchymosis is present in hanging

question: A body was found drowned in a stream. Where will hypostasis be seen in the body?
What type of autopsy is performed in the dead body of a drug addict or HIV patient?
A person found guilty is sentenced to death by hanging. What is the cause of death in judicial hanging?

answers.option: Neck fracture of the 2nd cervical vertebra

question: A person died from drowning. His lungs were clogged and froth was found coming out of his mouth and nose. What type of artifact is this?
Which incision is done on the scalp while preserving the facial features?
In an arterial blood gas (ABG) test, pH = 7.38, pO2 = 30 mmHg, and pCO2 = 50 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
In an arterial blood gas (ABG) test, pH = 7.32, pO2 = 30 mmHg, and pCO2 = 25 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A young woman was being treated with antibiotics for postpartum sepsis since 2 days. She suddenly developed tachypnea and cyanosis. What will be found on lung biopsy?

A 45-year-old male smoker has a dry cough. On physical examination, he has crackles and clubbing. The radiograph shows honeycomb cysts and traction bronchiectasis. What type of interstitial pneumonia does the man most likely have?
What part of the manuscript is the last to be finalized?
Exposure to air pollution increases the risk of which of the following diseases?
Which of the following is the cause of cat-scratch disease?
What is a type I or alpha error in hypothesis testing?

answers.option: The null hypothesis is true and accepted
The null hypothesis is false and rejected
The null hypothesis is true and rejected
The null hypothesis is true and not rejected
The null hypothesis is false and not rejected

question: Which of the following is characterized by repeated bouts of binge eating along with a desire to lose weight?
Which of the following is an example of medical writing that comprises academic writing for marketing purposes?
Which gas is known as sewer gas?
Which greenhouse gas contributes the most to global warming?
Acid-fast bacilli in macrophages and noncaseating granulomas are seen in which of the following conditions?

A man, working in a sandblasting factory, develops shortness of breath, and a non-productive cough. His pulmonary function tests show a restrictive pattern. He takes no respiratory precautions in his workplace. Which of the following diseases has he most likely developed?

A 36-year-old female, a mother of three children, comes to the emergency department with shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. She has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and is on oral contraceptives for 1 year. With this history, what will be the best investigation choice?
Which of the following is mandatory for doing any kind of autopsy?
In what case is a psychological autopsy performed?
Exhumation is made mandatory in case of which of the following?

answers.option: In case of an unclaimed body
If the medicolegal officer missed something

question: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with complaints of coughing and wheezing after swallowing a 5 rupees coin. The pulmonologist used a bronchoscope to perform foreign body aspiration to remove the coin. What is the most expected place for obstruction?
What is found in freshwater drowning?
Which expectorant acts directly on the airway and through reflex?
Which of the following statements about antitussives is correct?
A negative autopsy is observed in which of the following situations?

answers.option: Body is in advanced stage of decomposition

question: Long-term oxygen therapy is initiated in patients at which of the following partial pressures of arterial blood gases?
Which method is used to diagnose and classify chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
A non-selective β₂ agonist is given for bronchodilation in asthma. What unwanted side effect can it produce?

A firefighter has failed his yearly fitness exam. His chest x-ray shows no masses or hilar lymphadenopathy but diffuse pulmonary infiltrates with reticular shadowing and honeycombing can be seen. There are no anti-nuclear or anti-Scl-70 antibodies. On spirometry, FEV1 is almost normal and FVC is considerably decreased. What is the patient suffering from?
Which two anti-tuberculosis drugs are considered bactericidal?

Secondary mycobacterial infection should always be an important consideration in human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive patients who present with pulmonary disease. Which organism is most likely responsible for causing it?
Isoniazid causes anemia and neuritis due to which of the following reasons?

answers.option: Interferes with pyridoxine metabolism and induces its deficiency
Has toxic effects on red blood cells and neurons
Interferes with post-translational modification of proteins

question: A lady presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, purulent cough, and dyspnea. Chest x-ray shows lobar consolidation. What is the most common cause of lobar pneumonia?
A newborn baby is in respiratory distress due to the lack of surfactant. Which of the following cells is the reason behind this?

A 52-year-old man, a heavy smoker, presents to the clinic with complaints of cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. His chest X-ray shows an ill-defined 0.4 cm mass involving the left hilum of the lung. Bronchial washing shows lymphocyte-like cells. The doctor infers from the biopsy that surgical removal is not helpful in this case. What is the most likely diagnosis?
What instrument is used to assess the volume of inspired and expired air?
What findings suggest that a pleural effusion has become empyema?

answers.option: Glucose less than 60 mg/dL in pleural fluid
Pleural LDH less than serum LDH
Glucose more than 60 mg/dL in pleural fluid

question: A man who works as a laborer in the ship-breaking industry comes to the outpatient department with progressive dyspnea and pleural plaques in both lungs. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A child presents to the clinic with the complaint of severe chronic sinusitis. He is found to have increased sodium chloride concentration on a sweat test. He also had a problem with meconium expulsion at birth. Which of the following conditions is he at risk of developing?
According to the transtheoretical model (TTM), what does precontemplation mean?

answers.option: The person has acknowledged the problem but is not ready to change his behaviour yet
Not acknowledging that there is a problem

question: A 55-year-old woman has had progressive dyspnea and a dry cough for many days. She has also experienced weight loss. She does not smoke and has also joined a church lately. Imaging studies show a peripheral mass. After carrying out thorough investigations, the doctor decides to resect it. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a cough and mucopurulent sputum. She has been having repeated infections since childhood. Chest x-ray shows dilation of bronchi. What is the likely pathogenesis of her disease?

answers.option: Bronchial wall damage due to recurrent inflammation

question: A 69-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with a non-productive cough and chest pain. The doctor suspects pneumonia. Chest X-ray shows patchy lung infiltrates. Cultures are inconclusive. The specimen has been sent for molecular testing. What is the most likely cause of his disease?

A 38-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of episodes of cough and wheezing. The episodes are recurrent and have been happening for 5 years in winter and with mild respiratory infections. He is normal between the episodes. There is no family history of asthma or allergy. His chest radiographs are normal. IgE and WBC count is normal. Which of the following is the cause of his condition?

answers.option: Production of major basic protein by eosinophils
Hyperreactive airways due to inflammation from viral infection

question: A 40-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with a persistent cough. On examination, he is cyanosed and is later diagnosed as a case of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Which material is responsible for damaging pulmonary tissue in this condition?
What is the most common hazard of autopsy?

answers.option: Viral infections like hepatitis B and AIDS

question: A research mentor asks his students to write research proposals that are feasible. What does he mean by feasible?
